so much for my attempt to draw a "digital display"... just think of a 
digital alarm clock and label the individual LED components 
appropriately working top to bottom left to right.

Karl

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "blackkm7" <karl.black@h...> wrote:
> I've run thousands of jNeat generations on this "simple" 
> classification experiment without it getting close to a solution.  
> Any suggestions would be appreciated!
> 
> Experiment Description:
> Evolve a network that takes 4 inputs representing the binary 
numbers 
> 0 thru 15, that produces 7 "LED" outputs that represent the 
> equivalent decimal (1's place) digital display of the number (like 
an 
> alarm clock). E.g. if the outputs are labeled A thru G
> 
>     A
>   -----
>   |   |
> B |   | C
>   | D |
>    ---
>   |   |
> E |   | F
>   |   |
>   -----
>     G
> 
> The binary input samples 0010 (deimal 2) and 1100 (decimal 12) 
should 
> both "turn on" the outputs ACDEG which represents a decimal digital 
> display "2". I.e. the outputs represented as binary should be: 
1011101
> 
> Results:
> So far all experiments on the full set of outputs have failed.  It 
> always reaches a local optimum and gets stuck for more than 3000 
> generations.  This, in spite of some amazingly complex evolved nets
> 
> When I run NEAT on a single output at a time (change the topology 
to 
> produce a single output, representing only one of the LED's instead 
> of all 7), occasionally after hundreds of generations it will find 
a 
> solution.  Interestingly, some of the single LED attempts converge 
> more quickly averaged over repeated runs, while others (like "D") 
> take much longer.
> 
> I've tryed all different kinds of combinations of the NEAT 
> parameters, and even tried a different activation function 
> (hyperbolic tangent instead of sigmoid) with similar dismal results 
> on the full set of outputs.
> 
> Any ideas?
> Thanks,
> Karl
